The aim of the Standard, Simple and Five Card Symbotica games is to score the maximum number of points. Points are scored based on the placing of the cards. In order to cater for different age groups, the scoring is either based on addition or multiplication.

The one player Symbotica Challenge consists of trying to get as close as possible to the full grid of 64 cards using the same placement rules as the other games but without any scoring.

The game appeals to a wide range of ages from children learning simple pattern matching, addition or multiplication right up to those adults who want to keep their mind fit.

Home Page: http://www.symbotica.com/

Name: Underdog Game
Description:
This is a children's game for 2 to 4 players Ages 5 - 12.

This is believed to be the first Underdog board game as it was released in 1964, the year that the animated series voiced by Wally Cox first appeared on NBC.

This is a humorous game of give and take in which the players try not to become the Underdog.  The game has all the familiar cartoon characters.  When a playing piece stops on a space, the player draws a card.  If the card matches the character on the space, the player keeps the card.  If the playing piece lands on one of the bright yellow Underdog spaces, the player takes a card from each player.  The game comes with a gameboard, four wooden playing pieces, die, and 24 cards.

Name: Terrytoons Pop-Outs
Description:
This is a children's game for those Ages 3 - 6.

This variation of the game Bingo involves picture puzzles of cartoon characters Dinky Duck, Goose and Gander, Heckle and Jeckle, and Mighty Mouse.

Name: Barcode Battler
Description:
In this game, warriors and wizards are fighting against each other. These characters are... barcodes !

The game consists in an electronic device with a barcode scanner included, and a set of cards representing heroes, enemies and equipments. There's also a few blank cards that you can use to create your own characters with any barcode found on common products.

Name: Hector Heathcote
Description: This children's game for Ages 7 - 12 was based upon a Saturday morning NBC cartoon show.  The game includes four Hector playing pieces and a Cannon-type bowling device.

Name: Combat Moonbase
Description:
Combat Moonbase is a set of rules for tactical spaceship combat using 1/400 miniatures. Rules are provided (in Attack Wargaming's inimitable style) for lasers, missiles, plasma torpedoes, ECM, chaff, and landing and taking off from planets.

Information is provided for three types of ships, two from the Eastern Coalition and Western Alliance (who are fighting over the titular moonbase) and one from the alien Thook.

Name: Kick the Can
Description:
The game's arch-shaped track is designed to look like a pinball game.  There are only 21 game track spaces.  The game uses a die instead of a spinner and has a metal piece with a spring that helps determine extra scoring by shooting the die along the inside of the arch boundary.  Where the die lands determines the extra scoring.  The movement track has places with sayings such as "stubs toe -- go back 3 spaces," "steps on cat -- go back 2 spaces," "trips on shoe lace -- go back 3 spaces," and "sees bully -- go back 4 spaces."

The game uses a different artistic style for the inside game and the box exterior.

Name: Election '68
Description: Election '68 (CreaTek, 1967) does an excellent job of featuring the early candidates in caricature form on cards, and shows the probable front runners for each party on the cover: Richard Nixon for the Republicans; Robert Kennedy for the Democrats with Lyndon Johnson who had decided to not seek re-election "presiding" over both.

Name: Presidential Election Game: Goldwater For President
Description:
from notes from Tony and Theresa Game Wardens

This single, large piece of cardboard comprises the entirety of the Presidential Election Game: Goldwater For President (Kom-Pak, 1964).

One unusual feature of this game is that all pieces are furnished as cutout parts, including the six-sided die. Another noteworthy feature is the small Barry Goldwater circle, which presumably was intended to fill the empty circle on the board reserved for the 36th President. This game is marked, "Approved by the Republican Nat'l Committee."
